titleStmt.title: The ioyfull entrie of the Dukedome of Brabant & the articles agreed vpon, and graunted by their lordes, and confirmed by the Emperour Charles the Fifte, and solemnely sworne by Philippe his sonne King of Spaine. Anno 1549. Set foorth to the viewe of al louers of the trueth, who openly may see therein, how the same in no wise is perfourmed, (the Lord in his mercie emende it) but to the contrary, in place of getting and preseruing of priuiledges and liberties, they are through the inspiration of the Pope and his allyed, with all crueltie and tyrannie, broken, taken away, & totally voyd. Printed at Delft in Dutch, and Englished by R.V.S. 1581.
Treaties, etc. Brabant (Duchy), 1549-07-05
titleStmt.author: Holy Roman Empire. Emperor (1519-1556 : Charles V)

This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The ioyfull entrie of the Dukedome of Brabant & the articles agreed vpon, and graunted by their lordes, and confirmed by the Emperour Charles the Fifte, and solemnely sworne by Philippe his sonne King of Spaine. Anno 1549. Set foorth to the viewe of al louers of the trueth, who openly may see therein, how the same in no wise is perfourmed, (the Lord in his mercie emende it) but to the contrary, in place of getting and preseruing of priuiledges and liberties, they are through the inspiration of the Pope and his allyed, with all crueltie and tyrannie, broken, taken away, & totally voyd. Printed at Delft in Dutch, and Englished by R.V.S. 1581.
Treaties, etc. Brabant (Duchy), 1549-07-05
titleStmt.author: Holy Roman Empire. Emperor (1519-1556 : Charles V)
Cuba. Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias.
Brabant (Duchy). Treaties, etc. Holy Roman Empire, 1549-07-05.
Spain. Sovereign (1556-1598 : Philip II)

publicationStmt.publisher: By Robert VValdegraue, dwelling without Temple-bar, neere vnto Sommerset-House,

notesStmt.note: The title refers to the "Blijde Inkomst" of 3 Jan. 1356, but this is in fact a separate agreement.
Dated at end: Giuen in our citie of Louaine, the fift day of Iuly, anno. 1549. ..
Running title reads: Articles agreed vpon by the king of Spaine.
Reproductions of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
Appears on reels 177 and 275 (same copy filmed twice).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Ioyfull entrie of the Dukedome of Brabant, & the Articles agreed vpon, and graunted by their Lordes, and confirmed by the Emperour Charles the Fifte, and ≈øolemnely Sworne by Philippe his ≈øonne King of Spaine. Anno 1549.

Set foorth to the viewe of al louers of the trueth, who openly may ≈øee therein, how the ≈øame in no wi≈øe is perfourmed, (the Lord in his mercie amende it) but to the contrary, in place of getting and pre≈øeruing of Priuiledges and liberties, they are through the in≈øpiration of the Pope and his allyed, with all crueltie and Tyrannie, broken, taken away, & totally voyd.
Printed at Delft in Dutch, and Engli≈øhed by R. V. S. 1581.
PRINTED AT LONDON BY RObert VValdegraue, dwelling without Temple-bar, neere vnto Sommer≈øet-Hou≈øe.

div.head: ¬∂ The e≈øtabli≈øhing of the King of Spaine, in gouernment of the Lowe countreys vppon tho≈øe Articles following, to the which he is mo≈øt ≈øolemply ≈øworne.

opener.signed:
CHarles by the grace of God, Emperour of Rome, alwaies augmenting of ye Empire, King of Germanie, of Castille of Leon, of Grenade, of Arragon, of Nauarre, of Naples, of Sicille, of Maiorque, of Sardaine, the I≈øles of Indies, and fa≈øt lande of the Occean ≈øeas, Archduke of Austria, Duke of Borgundie, of Letricke, of Brabant, of Limbourgh Luxenbourg, and of Shelre. Earle of Flanders, of Artoys, of Borgoingne, Palatine and of Haynolde, of Holland and Zealand, of Ferrette, of Haguenault, of Namur, and of Zutphen, Prince of Swaue, Marquis of the holye Empire, Lorde of
Free≈øland, of Salins, and of Mechlen, of the Citie, Cities, and Landes of Vtreht Ouery≈ø≈øel, and of Groening, Dominator in A≈øia, and Affricke.
And we Philip by the ≈øame grace, prince of Spaine, of both the Secillies of Ieru≈øalem, &c. Lord of Hub≈øburgh of Flanders, &c.
opener.salute: To al them yt ≈øhal ≈øee the≈øe pre≈øents, gretings.

div.p:
Fora≈ømuch & to ≈øhew and declare the better our inheritant laÃÑds on this ≈øide & ye good and true ≈øubiectes therof, the vpright loue, fauour, and affection, which we Emperors alwayes haue borne and yet are bearing. Not requiring, but that which is and concerneth their commoÃÑ welfaring, re≈øt, peace, and a≈ø≈øuraunce. We haue ≈øent for, and cau≈øed to come ouer, our welbeloued prince of Spaine, to the intent that hee him ≈øelfe ≈øhoulde ≈øee, examine, vi≈øite, and knowe the ≈øaid our heritable landes of the Low countreys, proceeded of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and likewi≈øe ≈øhewe vnto the ≈øubiectes thereof, the good and ≈øpecial true loue and effection which he beareth vnto them. To the intent they ≈øhuld be more enclined, affectioned, and to bee bounde to remaine, and for the ≈øame certaine other ≈øpeciall rea≈øons, haue we re≈øolued,
and concludteh him to be receiued, helde, and ≈øworne, by the States and members of all our ≈øaide heritable landes, and among others by the Prelates, Nobles, & foure chiefe Cities of this our Dukedome and countreys of Brabant, for their naturall and chiefe≈øt Prince and Lorde, for him his heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, to bee occupied after our di≈øcea≈øe, the ≈øaid our Dukedome and countreys of Brabant, with his appurtenances, as iu≈øt and lawfull Lorde thereof: All which we haue cau≈øed to be propo≈øed and declared to the afore≈øaid three States of Brabant in our pre≈øence, and in the pre≈øence of our welbeloued ≈øi≈øter, and Aunte of our Prince, lady Marie Queene Dawgiere≈ø≈øe of Hungarie, of Boheme, &c. In our ab≈øence Regent and gouernour of our ≈øaid heritable landes. And that our will and intention hath beene, and is yet, that our ≈øaide ≈øonne the Prince as our only heire to come, likewi≈øe do graunt, promi≈øe, and ≈øweare the ioyfull income, after the olde order and cu≈øtome. But becau≈øe that in the ioyfull income which we and our forefathers haue ≈øworne, are in ≈øome points and matters already done, and totally perfourmed,
others which are not to bee perfourmed, nor rea≈øonably for the common wealth and quietne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øame countrey. And con≈øidering that our ≈øaid ≈øonne thinkes and doeth require all that which hee ≈øhall graunt, promi≈øe, & ≈øweare vnto them pointly to ob≈øerue and perfourme. So haue we cau≈øed to be made communicacion with the afore≈øaide three States of Brabant, for to haue our ioyful incomming to be ≈øeene ouer and vi≈øited, becau≈øe that they them ≈øelues might con≈øider al that which oughte therein to be moderated and variated. And for to refourme the articles which ≈øhoulde bee found not to be ob≈øeruable, nor mainteined. According to which ther had bene kept, diuers communicacions and a≈ø≈øemblings together, ≈øo that finally after diuers delayings, adui≈øements, opinions, & reports re≈øpectiuely made one to another, they haue in that behalfe con≈øented and willed them ≈øelues, according to ye acte hereupon made, ≈øigned by them. And al≈øo we Prince hauing ≈øure and well vnder≈øtanded the afore≈øayde ioyfull income of our Lorde and Father, and likewi≈øe the adioyned letters and additions thereof, with al≈øo the other adioyned
letters and graunts of the ≈øayd our grandfather mentioned in the la≈øt article of our afore≈øaid ioyful income, being truely tran≈ølated and ≈øette ouer in the Spani≈øh tongue, and likewi≈øe al≈øo the vocation and moderation therof, & that which therunto is ≈øet by, according to the contention of the afore≈øaid acte, willing and reque≈øting according to the good plea≈øure of our ≈øaid Lord and Father, the common countrey of Brabant, and the good people inhabitantes and ≈øubiects therof, their rights, priuileges, freedomes, cu≈øtomes, v≈øances, and old proceedings, ob≈øerue and perfourme, e≈øpecially con≈øidered, the great and manifolde ≈øeruices, fauours, and fidelitie by them at diuers times done, and ≈øhewed to our forefathers, Dukes, and Duce≈ø≈øes of Brabant, of di≈øcea≈øed memorie, and among others to our remembred Lorde the Emperour our Lord and father, as true ≈øubiects ought to do to their Lords. And as we tru≈øt that they likewi≈øe will do to vs hereafter. So we haue the will, and knowledge of our ≈øayde Lorde and Father, in this our receiuing and holding within the Citie of Louaine, and with our good knowledge and will al≈øo graunted, giuen
and con≈øented, graunt, giue, and con≈øente, ≈øearch, priuileges, poyntes, and fa≈øtne≈ø≈øe of rights, as here do followe, promi≈øing and ≈øwearing vnto them for vs, our heyres and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, after the di≈øcea≈øe of our ≈øayde Lorde and father, (whome God almightie graunt a good long pro≈øperous life,) feruent and ≈øtedfa≈øtly to ob≈øerue and mainteine and cau≈øe to bee ob≈øerued and mainteined, without breaking, interruption, for euer and euer.

1 That wee ≈øhall bee the good and true Lordes, and ≈øhall not do nor ≈øuffer to bee done to them, any force and wil in any wi≈øe, and that we ≈øhal not meddle our ≈øelues, nor ≈øuffer to be medled with the forraine lawes and iudgements. But that we ≈øhall v≈øe and cau≈øe to be v≈øed al our Prelates, alme≈øhou≈øes, Banrotches, Noble, and good people, and ≈øubiectes of our Cities and Townes of the Country of Brabant and Ouermaze, v≈øe & cau≈øe to be v≈øed in al matters with iudgement, and with lawe according to the lawes of the Cities and Benches, whereas the ≈øame ought to be done and ≈øhal appertaine. And yt the Iudges of our ≈øaid Country ≈øhal be bound to keepe their terme times of law
without any meanes of prolongations by any their doings or procurement. Re≈øerued that the fore≈øaide Iudges may prolong their termes of Lord≈øhips once, & no more.

2 Item, that the preuiledges and charters belonging to the ≈øayde countreys and good people, which they haue at this pre≈øeÃÑt, & herafter ≈øhal or may get in their countreys behalfe, ≈øhal remaine in the Ca≈øtle of V ‚Ä¢ uoorde, in the keeping of an hone≈øt wor≈øhipfull and well quallified man, borne and re≈øident in Brabant, therunto by the prince committed, or to be committed. Re≈øerued that the ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øionor ≈øhall be≈øworn by the Prince in the pre≈øence of the States or their Deputies: whereunto the Prealates and Nobilitie haue appoynted two Prelates, and two Noble men, which the layde Prince, or his Deputie, ≈øhal commodiou≈øly finde at the time when as the ≈øayde Commi≈ø≈øioner ≈øhall do his othe. And ≈øhall the thirde e≈øtate, to wit, the foure chiefe cities (thereunto being required by ye prince) apoint one out of euery chiefe citie which ≈øhall bee called thereunto for to be likewi≈øe by the ≈øwearing of the ≈øame othe, which othe ≈øhall be and ≈øhall conteine to bee good
and true to the ≈øaide Prince, and not to alienate nor variate change nor hide the ≈øame charters and priuileges by him ≈øelfe, nor any others in any wi≈øe. And that the ≈øaide Commi≈ø≈øioner ≈øhall giue ouer and deliuer to the States a generall Inuentary of the priuiledges and charters belonging to the ≈øaid countrie and good people of Brabant, which ≈øhall be made by the ≈øayd Commi≈ø≈øioner & keeper, in the pre≈øence of the Chancellor of Brabant, ≈øo extendeth that euery one of the States may knowe thereby, that which concerned and belonged vnto them, for to be kept by the ≈øaid States into their coffer, & to deliuer to no man in perticular the copie, But the ≈øame States, and euery of them, and of the foure chiefe≈øt cities, at their reque≈øt and by order of the ≈øaide Chancellour ≈øhall haue the ≈øight thereof, Moreouer that the ≈øaide keeper of the charters ≈øhall be bounde (being thereunto required) by the ≈øaid States or any of them to giue the ≈øight and copie auctentyke of ≈øuch originall letters, as the ≈øame States, Citie or Cities or any of them ≈øhall require and haue neede of, and that by order of the ≈øaide Prince or his Coun≈øell of Brabrant.

3 Item, that we ≈øhall neuer bynde our ≈øelfe as Duke of Brabant, and countie of Limborch, and for the matters of the Lord≈øhippes of the ≈øame countries, for to make warres, nor lay to gage, nor cau≈øe for to be done vpon any of them, except it be by the coun≈øell and wil of our cities and Countrie of Brabant, and that wee ≈øhall not ≈øcale, nor promi≈øe other matters wherewithall our countreys, limittes, or cities, or any of them of the ≈øayd countries, or the lawes, lyberties, & priuileges ≈øhalbe interrupted, or dimini≈øhed, wherewithal our countreys and ≈øubiectes thereof might be put to charges, or lo≈ø≈øe in any wi≈øe.

4 Item, that we ≈øhall take vpon vs the tytle and armes of Lotrycke, of Brabant, of Limbourgh, and Marquis of the holy Empire as it appertayneth, and that wee ≈øhall cau≈øe to be made and gathered a ≈øeale according to the ≈øaide Title and armes, with a ≈øpeciall marke, different of our other ≈øeale, which wee ≈øhall, nor may cau≈øe to be altered, or any others to make, or cau≈øe to be counterfeited thereafter, neyther will nor con≈øent therunto in any wi≈øe, except it were for rea≈øonble cau≈øes which we ≈øhoulde then
do, by the con≈øent of their States of the ≈øaid countrie of Brabant, which ≈øeale ≈øhall alwayes remaine in the ≈øaide countie of Brabrant, and not be caried thereout, and therewithall ≈øhall be ≈øealed al the matters belonging to our ≈øaide countie of Brabant and Ouermaze, and the ≈øubiectes thereof, and none others, and that the letters therof ≈øhal be made by one of our Secretaries that ≈øhal be ordeyned for the matters of Brabant.

5 Item, that we ≈øhall entertayne ≈øeuen wor≈øhipfull per≈øons, whereof the one ≈øhalbe Chancellour and ≈øealer, bound within our ≈øaide countrie of Brabant, ≈øpeaking three languages, ≈øcilicet, Latin, Frenche, and Dutch, which ≈øhall keepe our ≈øaide ≈øeale, and the fore borne re≈øident and inherited in our ≈øaide countrie of Brabant and that doe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe of them≈øelues, or by mariage in our ≈øaid countrie of Brabant Barronnies, and the other two of our part of our coun≈øell, as we ≈øhal thinke be≈øt vnder≈øtanding dutch, wt which ≈øeuen and others thereunto, nowe ordeined them that ≈øhal plea≈øe vs hereafter to the ≈øaide coun≈øell to ordeine, wee or our gouernoure, or gouernaunt generall ≈øhall cau≈øe to meddle and doe all the matters of
the ≈øame Countries, & the inhabitants therof concerning Iu≈øtice, and all that is thereunto depending, It be of Proui≈øions ordinaries of Iu≈øtice of ≈øtatutes, placeats edictes, ordinances, commaundements or others by coun≈øell and adui≈øement of the ≈øame, and the afore≈øaide coun≈øell of Brabant, without that there ≈øhall bee done any let or impediment, nor that they ≈øhall ≈øtand to the order of any man, but of vs, our gouernour or gouernant general, and al them that ≈øhal be ours or our ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, Coun≈øellers, or ≈øecretaries, before they ≈øhall meddle with office of coun≈øell or offices by ≈øuch faith, fidelitie, and othe as they ≈øhall haue done to our ≈øucce≈ø≈øoures, that they to oure three ≈øtates in our countries behalfe, ≈øhall promi≈øe and graunte that they ≈øhall neuer ≈øtande ouer or come by, make letters, ≈øigne ≈øeale wherewithal any of our countries, Cities, Ca≈øtles, people reuennues or Lord≈øhips by water or by Land, laying on this ≈øide, or on the other ≈øide of the Maze, ≈øhalbe encombred, charged, ≈øold, alienated, giueÃÑ away, or acquited in any wi≈øe, except it be by con≈øent, and a≈ø≈øent of the afore ≈øaide three States, And if it be found that any of our
Coun≈øellers, do ≈øeale or the ≈øecretaries ≈øub≈øigne in their Coun≈øell, office, and ≈øeruice, and do ≈øo mi≈ørule them≈øelues: we ≈øhall then correct by coun≈øell of the nobilitie and good Citties of our ≈øaide countrie of Brabant, or the mo≈øte part thereof.

6 Item, that wee henceforth ≈øhall take nor mainteine none to our ≈øworne coun≈øell of Brabant: except they be good men borne of lawful birth in our countrie of BrabaÃÑt, and re≈øident within our countrie, inherited or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing barronnies in our ≈øaide countrie proceeding of them≈øelues, or hauing them gottem by mariage, except the two of our coun≈øell which haue the ≈øaide Dutche tong.

7 Item that we ≈øhal ≈øet good men of our coun≈øell of Brabant, for to keepe a coun≈øell chamber in our behalfe, in the place wheras we ≈øhall keepe our re≈øidence in the ≈øaide Country, & if it did happen vs to be therewith, ≈øo ≈øhal we ordain the ≈øame to be kept within the ≈øame country, in a fit place, whiche ≈øhall haue full power, all men to di≈øcharge in our name, and that likewi≈øe our reckoning chamber ≈øhall be kept as it hath bene kepte vntill this time,

8 Item that all letters a≈øwell open as clo≈øed that ≈øhal be granted and & ≈øent foorth from heÃÑceforth in our name out of our coun≈øell of Brabant, either if it bee for vs, or at the reque≈øt of parties, ≈øhall be made di≈øpatched, & ≈øent in ≈øuch ≈øpeech as is ≈øpoken in the places, whereas they ≈øhal be ≈øent vnto.

9 Item yt we ≈øhal ≈øet no Chanceller, nor ≈øealer, into our Countries of Brabant, except he be of lawfull birth, born within our Country of Brabant, & there dwelling, inheriting po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing Barronies & in our ≈øaid country of his owne ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, or by marriage, ≈øpeaking three languages as afore≈øaide, and being apt & for the purpo≈øe, and profitable to the office and Lande, whiche Chancellor ≈øhall doe the othe to the ≈øame office belonging in our pre≈øence, and of the three ≈øtates to the v≈øe of the common countrie, after the ≈øort as here before is in one point comprehended, concerning the promi≈øes which our Coun≈øellers, Sealers, & Secretaryes, ≈øhall doe to the ≈øaide three States. And that our Secretary of Brabant, and the Clearke of oure freelandes ≈øhall be borne in Brabant: re≈øerued that we may ordein two ≈øecretaries, thogh they are
not borne in Brabant.

10 Item that our Chauncellor, & men of coun≈øell, Secretaries, the men of oure chamber of reckoninges in Brabant, and Clearks, Shirifs, Mai≈øters of Warrants, ma≈øters of Woods, and al others that haue any great offices or doinges, And likewi≈øe al≈øo all offices vppon the flat land, and al≈øo the Burugh ma≈øters, and Schepens of our Cities, and al others that do, or admini≈øter iu≈øtice in our or in our Va≈ø≈øelles name, ≈øhal ≈øweare vppon the holye Euangeli≈øtes that they ≈øhall ob≈øerue the≈øe our ioyfull ent ‚Ä¢ rye in all pointes, fora≈ømuche as it doeth belong to euery one of them, without any doinges to the contrary thereof with coun≈øel or deede in any wi≈øe,

11 Item that they of our Coun≈øell, and all other our officers, Iu≈øtices, Burughma≈øters, Schepens, men of Coun≈øell, men o ‚Ä¢ free landes, our farmers that haue power to a≈øke iudgement, and to giue iudgement and likewi≈øe that keep offices & ≈øeruices in our ≈øaide Country of Brabant, of what offic ‚Ä¢ ther be none re≈øerued, both in cities, town ‚Ä¢ & villages, ≈øhal be ≈øworne, Doing their e ‚Ä¢ that they ≈øhall not cau≈øe to bee taken an ‚Ä¢
golde, goods, gifts nor any kind of things, not cau≈øe nor ≈øuffer to be promi≈øed or taken by them≈øelues or by any other, for to aduance or to hinder, but that they ≈øhall do to all men a≈øwell rich as poore, Equitie and Iu≈øtice without any di≈ø≈øembling, Moreouer that they doe not haue re≈øpect vppon Burughma≈øters, Schepens, Coun≈øelles, goodes, monie, giftes, nor any manner of ≈øeruices, good deedes, giuen or promi≈øed, nor offered, or cau≈øe to be offered, giue nor offer, nor cau≈øed to be offred in their names nor required, or praying therefore in any wi≈øe, and who≈øoeuer doth to the contrary, that in no wi≈øe ≈øuche neuer ≈øhall or may enter in our coun≈øell, ≈øeruice, nor in any lawe or gouernement of our Cities, Townes, or Villages.
12 Item that our Countreys of Lymburgh and beyond the Maze ≈øhall remain for euer with our countrey of Brabant.

And that they neuer ≈øhalbe ≈øeperated thereof, that we likewi≈øe ≈øhall relea≈øe, and di≈øcharge our other countreys of ouer Maze, as we ≈øhall be able to do, and bring them to our countrey of Brabant, for to remaine with them, without being ≈øeparated.
That moreouer to the ≈øaide our Countreys of Brabant, ≈øhall remaine the Earle and Oyen with their appurtenaÃÑces, and others which are thereof alienated. And ≈øpecially to procure ≈øo much, that through the afore≈øayd place of Oyen, at this pre≈øent is out of our hands, that notwith≈øtanding the ≈øame place bee brought and ≈øet agayne into our hands, and remaine together as it hath bene before, if right may be done. And that we, our landes, and ca≈øtles of ouer Maze, with all their appurtenaunces, ≈øhall not encomber any more or further, then there are encombred at this pre≈øent time. And when they ≈øhall come into our hands and power, that wee ≈øhall then immediatly cau≈øe them to bee a≈øhamed, with our ≈øaide countrey of Brabant without any delay, with good ≈øureties on this ≈øide of the Maze, and to deliuer the hou≈øes thereof to our Countreys, and the ≈øayde hou≈øes and townes to bee inhabited by Brabanders, or the ≈øame people of the ≈øame Countrey, and them that ≈øhall a≈ø≈øure our Countreys, ≈øo well with good ≈øureties re≈øident on this ≈øide of the Maze, ≈øo that we and our countrey ≈øhalbe well a≈ø≈øured thereof, that they ≈øhall not be ≈øeperated
of the ≈øayd our countreys in no wi≈øe. And that wee from thencefoorth neuer ≈øhall enlarge, nor incomber any more the ≈øaid countreis, ca≈øtles, & towns of ouer Maze in any wi≈øe. And that the ≈øubieces of our ≈øaid countreys of ouer Maze, ≈øhall keepe their lawes and Iu≈øtices, whereas it ≈øhall appertayne according to the v≈øe of the Benches.

13 Item, that we ≈øhal keepe al our ≈øubiects and people, of our Countreys, and Cities: and Townes of BrabaÃÑt, & ouer Maze, peaceably and quietly in the countreys of Hollande and Zelande, and all other Countreys to trauell by water and land, free and franke vpon their cu≈øtomes as they were wont to do. And that we moreouer, ≈øhall keepe our ≈øaide ≈øubiectes and people of our Country, Cities, and Towns, free & franke to trauell, pa≈ø≈øe, and repa≈ø≈øe, without any mole≈øtation of any debts & promi≈øes which we or our predece≈ø≈øours, might owe and be debuable or haue promi≈øed, or yt wee might owe and promi≈øe hereafter. Moreouer, we haue confirmed and allowed to our citizens of our Citie of Bolducke, and do confirme and allow by the≈øe pre≈øents, ≈øuch letters as they haue of Duke Iohn of Brabant, and
Lady Iacob, Duche≈ø≈øe in Beyre di≈øcea≈øed, concerning yt they ≈øhould be free of cu≈øtome in Hollande & Zealand for their marchandi≈øe: and we ≈øhall command our letters to be made thereof ≈øufficient, according to the letters, and as the countrey of Gealre, that they ≈øhall be likewi≈øe free of cu≈øtome, pa≈ø≈øe, and repa≈ø≈øe in the afore≈øaid countrie, according to ye leters which they haue likewi≈øe thereof. And if it were ≈øo, that any of due ≈øubiectes by rea≈øon of debts, or promi≈øes of our ≈øaid prodece≈ø≈øors, or of vs ≈øhould fall in talke that we ≈øhal keepe them harmle≈ø≈øe thereof according to the contention of letter thereof written in Wallon.

14 Item, that we ≈øhall keepe open all our free ≈øtreetes as we ought to do without fraude or guile, for euery man to pa≈ø≈øe and repa≈ø≈øe there through paying their cu≈øtome, except of debtes or promi≈øes which hee did owe, or any forfaytes or offences which might haue offended.

15 Item, that we ≈øhall compell or cau≈øe to bee compelled all them that owe oure ≈øaide Countreys, any wayes, bridges, or pa≈ø≈øages through their land and goods, and cau≈øe them to amende well and ≈øufficiently
the ≈øame waies, bridges and pa≈ø≈øages from time to time, and if that therein were any fault, that in ≈øuch ca≈øe the chiefe citie where vnder ≈øuch wayes, bridges, and pa≈ø≈øages do lye, ≈øhall and may doe vppon the co≈øte and charges of him that is bound thereunto. And for that intent and for the ob≈øeruation of all neighbourly rights ≈øhall no man be excu≈øed.

16 Item, that from henceforth they that ≈øhall heare or haue part of our cu≈øtomes in our ≈øaid countreys, during the terme of their hyring. Al≈øo likewi≈øe them that haue parte in our cities in the coyning of money, ≈øhall or may not be ordeyned, are al≈øo likewi≈øe receiued,
17 Item, that what≈øoeuer man or per≈øon that is taken pri≈øonner within our ≈øayde Countreis of Brabant and ouer Maze, that we ≈øhall not cary nor cau≈øe to be caried out of our ≈øaide Countries.

18 Item that wee ≈øhall cau≈øe no money to bee coyned with our ≈øaide countrey of Brabant, except it bee by the will and con≈øent of the common Countreys afore≈øayde, and that the ≈øame peece of money, neuer ≈øhall or may bee made lyghter, and if that
it be made lighter, that we ≈øhall & may take the ≈øame vpon our coyners lyfe and goods, without delay or exception, & that the ≈øaide peece of money ≈øhalbe made in one of our free cities, and to warrant the ≈øame according to the contention of the charter, or letter heretofore made in Wallon.
19 Item, yt no man yt is not of a lawfull birth, ≈øhal or may be Coun≈øeller, Sheriffe, nor Iu≈øticer in Brabant, nor haue any office of vs.

20 Item, if in ca≈øe there did fall any difference or fightings in our ≈øayd Countreys that then all that bee not guiltie of the differents or fyghtings, ≈øhal haue fa≈øt and ≈øure quietne≈ø≈øe from the houre that the ≈øayd differents or fightings were done the ≈øpace of 24 houres, and who≈øoeuer do ≈øome what in the matter, ≈øhall be more quieter.
21 Item, that we ≈øhall graunt no man freedome in the countrey, any that hath ≈ølaine a man, except he bee fir≈øt reconciled with the friendes of the di≈øcea≈øed.

22 Item, that all them that hencfoorth ≈øhall giue the office of Maiors, Bayliffes, & they that haue them already at this pre≈øent time, that they ≈øhall ≈øerue the ≈øame, and
that they ≈øhall or may not, tran≈øport, nor ≈øel them, nor let them out, and them that keepe commons, or do other ≈øeruices, vppon the flat landes, and that haue aucthoritie to admini≈øter Iu≈øtice to the people, ≈øhal without delay, put in certain ≈øureties afore they ≈øhal or may haue their offices, & that in the hands of the Iu≈øtice, wheras they do ≈øerue in the behalfe of them that might ≈øuffer any hurt by them.

23 Item, that the officers of our country of Brabant, concerning Iu≈øtice ≈øhal not be let out, nor belent, but they ≈øhall bee ≈øerued as they haue bene v≈øed to haue kept and ob≈øerued in olde time to be ≈øerued, & all letting out thereof, ≈øhall be of no value nor effecte.

24 Item, yt we ≈øhal not ≈øuffer yt any man of our Countreys, ≈øhall or may arre≈øt, encomber, nor trouble out of our countreis for any matters where≈øoeuer they be, except he flee away before, without fraude or guile. Likewi≈øe al≈øo that who≈øoeuer of our ≈øubiectes doth call the other our of ye Countrey for to fight, or cau≈øe to bee called to fight, they ≈øhall forfaite two hundreth markes of fine golde, or other wayes to be corrected to the moderation and abiterment of them, of
the Coun≈øell of Brabant.

25 Item, if any of our ≈øubiects did robbe or ≈øteale, in our countrey of Brabant Ouermaze or the inhabitants thereof, & furthermore if they did lodge into their hou≈øes or ≈øuccoured, with their will and knowledge any enemies to vs as Duke of Brabant, Limburgh and Lordes of the Countreys of Ouermaze, that he ≈øhall lee≈øe his life and goods, and we ≈øhall nor may neuer graunt him againe the ≈øaid our countreys, & if that we did giue pardon to ≈øuch, that ≈øuch pardon ≈øhall be of none effect.

26 Item, that if in ca≈øe that any women were forced, ≈øo that ≈øhee did cry out, or that it were found to bee true, that it were done agayn≈øt her will, and that ≈øhe did remayne and continued with the man, then ≈øhall wee haue all her moueable goods, and her lands during her life, and after her death, ≈øhal the landes returne and ≈øucceede where as they ought to goe. And if ≈øhe did not remayne and continue by the man. In ≈øuch ca≈øe we ≈øhall haue neither the moueable goods neyther landes, and ≈øhal the man that committeth ≈øuch things, and all his helpers, and likewi≈øe they that with their knowledge do
helpe ≈øuccour and lodge him, doe forfaite their liues, and all their goodes for euer, if in ca≈øe that they may forfaite it, And if in ca≈øe that any man did by force conueie away any child being vnder age, either man childe or woman childe, ≈øo ≈øhall they and all their helpers haue forfetted their life and goodes without exception, and again≈øt the ≈øame no man ≈øhall haue excu≈øe by S. Peters man≈øhip, freedome of Cities, or others, but there ≈øhall bee v≈øed according to the lawes of the countries.

27 Item that women ≈øhall be accu≈øed, nor may bee accu≈øed which ≈øhoulde hinder him concerning blud≈øhed, neither of killing of any bodie, if in ca≈øe that hee dare tru≈øte him≈øelf to ≈øtande to the trueth thereof, and will come to his notgyltine≈ø≈øe, vntill the time that he ≈øhall be vanqui≈øhed. Re≈øerued that the officer of the place ≈øhall and maye arre≈øt him and keep him in pri≈øon, keeping the goodes of him in ≈øafetie, proceeding again≈øt him to the diffinitiue, either of condemnation or ab≈øolution.

28 Item that all our good people and ≈øubiectes of our Cities and Countries of Brabant and of Ouermaze, touching all
publique mi≈øhappes which may happen to come to their bodies, or their Children, ≈øeruantes and familie in what≈øoeuer ≈øorte or manner it were, Whereby they or any of them did come from life to death, without any proceeding faultes, the ≈øame ≈øhal ≈øtand and remaine free and franke of any forfets or confi≈øcation of their goodes. Of whiche mi≈øchance the mage≈øtrates of the places ≈øhall vi≈øite and con≈øider the matters (at the reque≈øt of the officer there) and that being done ≈øhall declare whether it ought to bee kept for mi≈øchance or not, And ≈øuche as they ≈øhall declare concerning the matter, ≈øhall be kept ob≈øerued and perfourmed, and if in ca≈øe, that there bee founde anye fault before, then ≈øhall and may the Magi≈øtrates puni≈øhe the offendor extraordinarily, according to the ≈øtate of the matter.

29 Item what≈øoeuer Cities, Townes Lord≈øhips or fortre≈ø≈øes, which we ≈øhall win with force of armes and common warre out of our countries of Brabant, vpon what ≈øoeuer Princes or Lordes, that they ≈øhall remaine and apperteine, to our Countrie of Brabant afore≈øaid, without turning backe againe, and that they ≈øhall v≈øe and doe
as our common country ought to do without parting likewi≈øe, as our ≈øaide Country of Brabant.
30 Item who≈øoeuer requireth adioining within our ≈øaid Countrie of Brabant and ouermaze, that wee ≈øhall cau≈øe him to haue again≈øt all men.
31 Item that Saint Peters men & all they that are of Saint Peters man≈øhapes companie ≈øhall be v≈øed and kepte as they ought to be kept by all equitie and Iu≈øtice.

32 Item if in ca≈øe that any parties two together beeing lowe per≈øons do goe to lawe concerning any goods, hauing within our ≈øaide countries and the ≈øaid parties hauing proceeded to the end and condemnation, ≈øo that the one do lee≈øe the proce≈ø≈øe or iudgement, and if the ≈øame wherefore the proce≈ø≈øe was there Iudged from him, and if he did ≈øhew the ≈øame to any prie≈øt. Cleark or other ≈øpiritual per≈øon, or likewi≈øe to any other for trouble, & mole≈øt the other out of the Countrie whiche had the iudgement vpon him, if al≈øo any per≈øon re≈øident within our Countrie had the aduancement of the matter, or that al≈øo any per≈øon re≈øidente, within our ≈øaid Countrie that did giue ouer
the matter to any others for to trouble and mole≈øt the partie out the Countries, that he yt did any of the≈øe things ≈øhal forfet two hundred Marks of golde, or otherwaies to be puni≈øhed at the arbitrement and moderation of them of our coun≈øell of Brabant.

33 Item that euery man ≈øhall and may keepe his own lands or cau≈øe, is to be watched and keepe Dogges therto, the clawes vn≈øhortened, without calenging and if that it hapened that any wilde, breake his neck, or ware hurted by the dogs, that the ≈øame ≈øhal ≈øo remaine laying, and that their dogs ≈øhal ≈øuffer no hurt or domage thereby, And that further euery man ≈øhall and may hunt Haires and foxes thorow out all Brabant without calenging, and likewi≈øe Connies without free warrands, and al≈øo flye with Haukes ouer all without chalenging.

34 Item that henceforth all knightes, yeomen and al good people re≈øident within our countrie of Brabant, ≈øhal and may hunt thorow all Brabant in his ≈øea≈øon, all manner of wilde Deere. Without chalenging, excepte. In the warrantes and Woodes of Zonien, of Zauenterlo, of Greothey≈øte, of Weeredale and Grootenhout, and to the
intent that this point ≈øhould be ob≈øerued, ≈øo haue we promi≈øed and ≈øworne, do promi≈øe and ≈øweare as is ≈øayd that we ≈øhall neuer make any di≈øending, nor cau≈øe, nor ≈øuffer to ‚Ä¢ e made any commandement to the contrary in any maner of wi≈øe, wherewithal the≈øe pointes ≈øhal ≈øuffer any let, hurt, or interrup
‚Ä¢ ion.

36 Item, that the debt ≈øhall be brought or deliuered by the lawes or warrants, and ‚Ä¢ wards excepted, debts proceeding of wood and tymber, of olde woods of the Prince, of the countrey, or of other warrantes of the Prince of the Countrey, or of other woods and wards, which from old time haue ≈øtood vnder the ≈øame lawe.

37 Item, that there ≈øhalbe in our countrey of Wallon, a Bayliffe, an hone≈øt man borne in our countrey of Brabant, and that
his clearke and other officers vnder borne, and likewi≈øe our other iu≈øtices & officers of our other 6. offices, ≈øhalbe borne of our couÃÑ trey of Brabant. And that the court of Genepia, ≈øhalbe kept as it was heretofore, ≈øo that no man that ≈øhall haue occa≈øion there to do, ≈øhal not be v≈øed without order of law.

38 Item, that al≈øo henceforth our ≈ømall Lords, Iu≈øtices, & Officers, ReÃÑtma≈øters, particularly ≈øhalbe borne within our countrey of Brabant, ≈øo that they ≈øhall nor may haue ≈øerued their ≈øayde offices by any outlandi≈øhbrone, of what ≈øo euer qualitie they be, and al≈øo our Lieftenants of our ca≈øtles, of our ≈øayd countrey of Brabant, ≈øhalbe inborne Brabants, except it were that they did po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe by them ≈øelues, or by mariage any olde po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øame countrey.
39 Item, that we ≈øhall keepe in ≈øtate our reformed Benches of Santhouen and of Vccle, as they nowe be, & as apperteineth, and that our Schepens of Vccle, ≈øhall keep their re≈øidence in Bru≈ø≈øell.

40 Item, that our citie of Antwerppe with the appurtenaÃÑces therunto belonging, ≈øhal remaine a≈ø≈øembled for euer to our good cities and countrey of Brabant, after ≈øuch
≈øort & manour, as ≈øhe was at the time when ≈øhe was ≈øeparated from Brabant, and likewi≈øe our Citie of Niuelle, as ≈øhe hath bene vntill this day.

41 Item, yt our a≈ø≈øembling daies which we ≈øhall hencefoorth ≈øende to our States, and countrey of Brabant, and of Ouermaze that we ≈øhal write alwaies for theÃÑ 14. daies before the day, that ye appointed a≈ø≈øembling pay ≈øhalbe kept (except the matters, wherefore we would keep the ≈øame a≈ø≈øemblings, did require great ha≈øte, and that we ≈øhal appoint ≈øuch commodious places, whereas our ≈øaide ≈øtates may free and frankly without danger, come & goe. And that euery one of our Prelats, Banrotches, Noble, cities, & Townes, of our ≈øaide country of Brabant and Ouermaze, before vs or el≈øwere, where as it apperteyneth ioyntly or particularly ≈øhall & may ≈øay open & declare their charges, and ≈øati≈øfie therewithall without any indignation or rebuke of vs, or by others to haue, or by vs to be di≈øfauoured in any wi≈øe, and if in ca≈øe that they therefore did get any hurt, the ≈øame do we promi≈øe to reueÃÑge vpon his or their liues & goods wtout remedy.

42 Item, that we ≈øhall alwayes ≈øet & ordaine
the countreys of our free lands in the places whereas we ≈øhall keepe place of re≈øidence, ≈øo that the parties, with their witne≈ø≈øes, & other things thereunto belonging may ea≈øily come therein, and when≈øoeuer it ≈øhal happen to vs, to be out of our countrey of Brabant, then ≈øhal we ordaine an hone≈ø ‚Ä¢ man, eyther our chiefe Sherife of Brabant or an other yt might bee councellor in Brabant: which in our ab≈øence, & as long as „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øhall plea≈øe vs, ≈øhall receiue the free lande ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ touching vs, and in our ab≈øence keepe th ‚Ä¢ court dayes in the place whereas the re≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
dence ≈øhalbe of our Coun≈øell chambers, an ‚Ä¢ he ≈øhall and may do all that appertayne ‚Ä¢ to the free lands, as we might do being o ‚Ä¢ ≈øelfe pre≈øent, without giuing, or forgiuin ‚Ä¢ any thing.

mi≈øe that we ≈øhal keepe, or cau≈øe to be ke ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
free ye ≈øaid prolonged dayes, as free as we are bonde for to keepe the principall dayes of the layre.

44 Item, that we ≈øhall not ≈øuffer our free faires of our cities of Bru≈ø≈øel, Antwerpe, and likewi≈øe the free fayres of the citie of Barrowe, or Zoam, to bee troubled or interrupted by any executions, coÃÑmandements, or di≈ø≈øentions, eyther by letters of mark, countermarkes, arre≈øtmentes, or their like, whiche we might graunt to the contrary, herein excepted our owne proper debtes, & al≈øo likewi≈øe ye ordinance made, or to bee made by vs, vppon the matter of coyning, which ordinance we will haue ob≈øerued, as wel in the afore≈øayd yerely faires as without, for to haue puni≈øhed and corrected the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors.

45 Item, yt we heÃÑceforth ≈øhal graÃÑt no priuiledges, nor liberties to the nations that keepe ≈øtaple in our countrey of FlaÃÑders, yt can or may preiudice & hinder our ≈øaide countreys, & inhabitants of Brabant.

46 Item, that we ≈øhal let ye inhabitants of our couÃÑ trey of Brabant, & their goods which they haue in other countreys and lands, or ≈øhal haue hereafter, & the fruites thereof ≈øhall ≈øuffer quietly and peaceably to haue and enioy, notwith≈øtaÃÑding any commandements, or defendings, which might be made to the contrary thereof. And likewi≈øe the marchants, and inhabitaÃÑts of all our countreys, lord≈øhips, and iuri≈ødictions, ≈øhall haue & may one among another, trafficke with their goods and marchandize, and walke, trauel, bargaine, ≈øel, bring their goods to the market
to ≈øell, where their liking ≈øhall thinke be≈øt, paying their ordinarie cu≈øtome and charges,

47 Item, that we ≈øhall cau≈øe to be kept, & remain vnto our couurtrey of Brabant, and in the handes of our ≈øaid countrey indi≈øtinctly, the landes, ca≈øtels, & townes of Hen≈øden, & S. Shertruydenbergh, with all their appurtenances, if in ca≈øe we may do it with right and rea≈øon, due both for the co≈øts and charges or ≈øhal kepe or cau≈øe to be kept vntil ye money which is den & ≈øuffered in ye a≈ø≈øigning of S. Shertruydenbergh, and the taking in, and prouiding of Hen≈øden, be duely and totally payde and re≈øtituted.

48 Item, if it happen that the cities of Holland, & Zeland, did not perfourme and ob≈øerue ≈øuch tractat or agreement made, and agreed betweene the Pen≈øionaries of Brabant, that we ≈øhal then do ful iu≈øtice like as if it were of other lawfull debt to the Pen≈øionaries of Brabant, hauing life pentioÃÑ vpon the ≈øaid cities of Holland, and Zeland, in commanding them and the inhabitants thereof.

49 Item, moreouer we haue promi≈øed, & by the≈øe pre≈øents do promi≈øe them of ye States of our countrey of Brabant, and Ouermaze, that our lands of our citie of Graue, with the lands of Duke Re≈ø≈øell, and Oyen, if the law will ≈øuffer it, ≈øhall alwayes remaine anexed and incorporated with our ≈øaid countreys of Brabant, & that the inhabitants of the ≈øaid land & citie of Graue, wt the ≈øaid land of Cuyc Re≈ø- & ≈øel Oyen, and ≈øhal haue their re≈øort to our coun≈øel
of Brabrant, & not be thereof in any wi≈øe ≈øeperates

50 Item, that all marchants of what≈øoeuer countrey or nation they be, a≈øwel outlaÃÑdi≈øh as inlandi≈øh ≈øhal and may go by water, to traffect, frequent: bie, & ≈øel peaceably, & quietly in our ≈øaid couÃÑtrey of Brabant, & Ouermaze, both among vs, & the ≈ømal lords of the ≈øame our countreis, in what cities, townes, or places, whereas it ≈øhal plea≈øe theÃÑ be≈øt, paying their cu≈øtome & charges, wtout that the ≈øaide marchants ≈øhal and may be compelled wt any re≈øtrict commandemeÃÑts, or defendings or other waies for to compel to ≈øel the more their marchandizes in one particuler place then in another. And that the ≈øaide marchants ≈øhall & may chu≈øe them≈øelues their dwelling places and kepe where it ≈øhal plea≈øe them, wtout that for any ≈øtaples ≈øake, or other wayes they ≈øhalbe let or hindred in their free wil, in any wi≈øe re≈øerued, that the ≈øame which is afore≈øaid, ≈øhall or may not larger be extended then to the Staples which are at this pre≈øent, within our countreys of Brabant.

51 Item, yt we will not nor may ≈øuffer to be done yt any of our ≈øubiectes of our countreys of Brabant and of Ouermaze ≈øhalbe, (for any ciuill matters) kept and detayned pri≈øoners in any ca≈øtelles, but that they ≈øhal keep their impri≈øonments within the countyes, except whereas there be no countyes, & that notwith≈øtanding the ≈øayde pri≈øoner putting in ≈øuretie for ciuil matters, for to ≈øtand to the law and
to accompli≈øh the iudgement, as apperteyneth to ye v≈øe of the place there, except he were arre≈øted vpon condemnations, or for our proper debts.
52 Item, that euery one of what ≈øtate or condition he ≈øhalbe, ≈øhall or may not fi≈øhe vpon the riuer of the Zenne as hath bin v≈øed, and was in the time of our olde grandfather, Duke Philip.

43 Item, when≈øoeuer we or the officers of our Iu≈øtices ≈øhall haue, apprehende, take pri≈øoner any man, by water or by land, which hath robd or ≈øtolen, or taken away anothers goodes, money, or ≈øub≈øtance, and that he had yet the ≈øame goods, or knew ye ≈øame goods where they were ≈øold, ≈øo ≈øhall ye ≈øame goods not being forfaited, but the officer vnder whoÃÑ this ≈øhal happen, ≈øhalbe bound to re≈øtitute, or cau≈øe to be re≈øtituted to the party from whom it was takeÃÑ and ≈øtolen, if in ca≈øe the ≈øaid partie can proue it lawfully to be is own, and that it appeareth lawfully to be his owne, re≈øerued that he ≈øhal be bounde to pay to the officer which did this arre≈øt or apprehen≈øion, his rea≈øonable ≈øallary at the di≈øcretion of the Magi≈øtrats of that ≈øame place where this was done.

44 Item that henceforth ≈øhal nor may apprehend or arre≈øt any of the liberties of cities or otherwaies being vnder vs that are of a good name & fame, except the officer of the place ≈øhall fir≈øt and for mo≈øt haue taken full information of the ≈øu≈øpection, whervppon he woulde arre≈øt and apprehende him, and
that no man ≈øhall or may be put to ≈øharpe examinatione, xcept the officer ≈øhall fir≈øt and formo≈øte haue ≈øhewed his information to the Magi≈øtrates of the place, and that he be thereto condemned by iudgement of the magi≈øtrats, except it wer a priuiledged Crime, and whereof the magi≈øtrates of the flat land ought to haue no knowledge, and yt the knowledge-belongeth to vs and to our ≈øaid coun≈øel.

55 Item yt from hencefoorth for euer, no Maior Shirife-Bailife nor any other officers of our countries of Brabant, by vertue of tran≈øport of letter of Attornie, which they might haue of any maÃÑ, or yet accept, ≈øhal or may arre≈øt encoÃÑber attach & charge within their liberties by them≈øelues or any others, any inhabitantes of the ≈øaid our countries, or their goodes, by vertue of any debtes whiche the Cities, Townes and Villages, doe owe of rentes of Liffe-pen≈øions or other debts, and if they doe to the contrary, that the ≈øame ≈øhall be of no vallure, and be≈øide that, ≈øhal forfet to the Lord wheras this ≈øhalbe done tenne Andrewe Children.

56 If that henceforth there ≈øhall bee giuen no commens, almo≈ø≈øes of Lands and perpetual rents in no maner of wi≈øe, and that we ≈øhall do al our diligence, for to get and to haue reduction of the chaire of Rome of the Annates, of all the Cloi≈øters, & all Alm≈øhou≈øes which are or may be di≈øcomforted therin, more then they haue beene therein di≈øcomforted
heretofore, Re≈øerued that the afore≈øaid prelates alme≈øhou≈øes & cloi≈øters, ≈øhall finde & pay for the co≈øts and charges needefull to the ≈øaid reduction.

57 Item moreouer we haue confirmed and ratified, confirme and ratifie by the≈øe pattens al our prelates alm≈øehou≈øes Cloi≈øters, Banrotches knights, Cities, Townes, and all other oure ≈øubiectes and good people of our Countries of Brabant, Ouermaze, and all their lawes Liberties, Priuiledges, Charters, Cu≈øtoms, V≈øan≈øes and olde proceedings of lands which they haue, and are giuen, graunted, and ≈øealed them by our forefathers, Dukes and duce≈ø≈øes, and al≈øo them which they haue v≈øed, hanted, and where went to v≈øe and ≈øpecially the odde letter graunted to the ≈øaid three ≈øtates by our ≈øaid Duke Philip our olde grandfather di≈øea≈øed at his incomming of the date as the letters be of the ≈øaid incomming. Likewi≈øe two other letters graunted by the ≈øaide our grandfather di≈øcea≈øed the one of the date. 1451. the 20. daye of April, and ye other in the yere. 1457. 28. daies in Nouember, and likewi≈øe the two additions of the ioyful income of the Lorde, our father giuen at Ghaunte of the twentie day of April in the yere 1515 after Ea≈øter, and the other giuen at Bridges the 26. of April in the ≈øame yeare and doe giue them generally & ≈øpecially: if in ca≈øe they doe ≈øtand to ob≈øeruation, and are able to be oberu≈øed, to hold them firme and ≈øtabell for euer, for vs our heirs & ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, without breaking or doing
or cau≈øe to be done to the contrary in any wi≈øe.

58 Item we do promi≈øe them moreouer for vs our heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, that wee ≈øhall neuer alledge deui≈øe or propo≈øe, nor cau≈øe to be alleaged, as that we are not bound & deluable to keep & ob≈øerue the afore≈øaide liberties, lawes, Priuiledges, Charters, Cu≈øtomes, v≈øances, and olde v≈øes which when we haue heretofore confirmed & ratified in generall, becau≈øe and for that we haue not graunted and promi≈øed to them the ≈øaide pointes and articles, particularly, which we will that ≈øhall do no hurte, hinderance or preiudice to them, And becau≈øe that we will and de≈øire that all the afore≈øaid pointes, articles giftes, promi≈øes, confirmations, and a≈ø≈øurances, ≈øhal be kepte and remaine ≈øure and con≈øtantly for euer. So is it therefore that we haue them altogether generally promi≈øed in good faith to all the prelats, cloi≈øters, and alm≈øhou≈øes, Barons, knights, Cities, townes, and to all our good people and ≈øubiectes of the ≈øaide Countries of Brabant and Ouermaze to their heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, and do promi≈øe in good faith, and freendly ≈øworne vppon the holye Go≈øpel for vs, our heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øers that after the di≈ø≈øea≈øe of our Lorde and father, to keepe them fa≈øt and ≈øtedfa≈øtly, and there again≈øte neuer to doe or cau≈øe to be done, nor ≈øuffer to be done in any wi≈øe. And if in ca≈øe that we, our heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øoures did doe, ≈øay, or vppo≈øe here again≈øt or cau≈øed to bee
done, by our ≈øelfe or others in our name, in part or in all, in what≈øoeuer manner it were. So do we in that ca≈øe con≈øent & do wil our prelates, barrons, knights Cities and townes, and al others our ≈øaid ≈øubiectes that they ≈øhall do to vs, our heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours no manner of ≈øeruice, nor be obedient in no manner of Ca≈øes that we neede, or that wee might require & do reque≈øt of them vntil the time we ≈øhal haue made fullie amendes, and left and for≈øaken immediatly, all the matters afore mencioned, whereunto we will do, di≈øcerne, and declare, that immediatly, al our offices doing to the contrary of this my incomming, ≈øhall be left, for≈øaken, and that al henceforth ≈øhall or may be attempted, ≈øhalbe of none effect and ≈øhall not be ob≈øerued in any wi≈øe hereafter. And all without fruade or guile. In witnes of which things and for perpetuall a≈ø≈øurance, haue wee Emperour and prince afore≈øaid cau≈øed our ≈øeale hereunto to be hanged. Giuen in our Citie of Louaine, the fift day of Iuly, Anno. 1549. of our empire of vs Charles the 30. and of our Realmes of Ca≈øtile, and others. 34. Thus ≈øub≈øigned, Charles, Philippe, & vnderneath is written, By the Emperor, & the ≈øaide Prince, & ≈øigned by the audience, and fir≈øt Secretary Verricken, and this Letter was ≈øealed with the ≈øeale of the emperor & prince in red waxe with gold and black-≈øilke ≈øtrings. And vnderneth was written, Collationated and found agreed with the originall, By me I. Facuwez.
